questions.question:
Question 1: A 30-year-old woman presented with purulent vaginal discharge associated with fever, 
malaise, and inguinal pain. A Pap smear revealed the following findings. What is the 
causative agent?
questions.explanation:
The given image of Pap smear shows cells with ground glass nuclei, viral inclusions, 
multinucleation, and margination of chromatin. These findings are characteristic of herpes 
simplex infection. Some infections of the female genital tract and their diagnostic features are given below: Infections 
Diagnostic features Herpes simplex

s fungal hyphae

questions.question: Question 2: What are the cystic remnants of mesonephric ducts in the cervix and vagina called?
questions.explanation:
Cystic remnants of mesonephric ducts in the cervix and vagina are termed Gartner duct cysts. The mesonephric (Wolffian) ducts normally regress in females. Its remnants may persist into 
adult life as epithelial inclusions adjacent to the ovaries, tubes, and uterus. In the cervix and 863 
Sold by @itachibot vagina, these ducts may be cystic and are termed Gartner duct cysts. The following images show the embryological development of the mesonephric duct and its 
persistence into adult life.

questions.question:
Question 3: 853 
Sold by @itachibot The following histological image depicts a pathology in which of the following sites?
questions.explanation:
The given histopathological image shows benign papillary projections covered with columnar 
secretory epithelium and underlying myoepithelial cells. These are commonly seen in papillary 
hidradenoma of the vulva. It presents as a sharply circumscribed nodule, most commonly on the labia majora or interlabial 
folds. Like the breast, the vulva also contains modified apocrine sweat glands. Its histologic 
appearance is identical to that of intraductal papilloma of the breast. 864 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: A 3-year-old girl presents with a mass protruding from the anterior vaginal wall that appears 
like grape clusters. Histopathological examination reveals tadpole cells. What is the most 
likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The most likely diagnosis is embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma (sarcoma botryoides). It is an uncommon vaginal tumor composed of malignant embryonal rhabdomyoblasts. It is most 
frequently found in infants and in children < 5 years of age. They are locally invasive tumors 
that cause death by penetration into the peritoneal cavity or by obstruction of the urinary tract. Grossly, polypoid, rounded, bulky masses that appear like grape clusters can be seen. On 
microscopy, small tumor cells with oval nuclei, and small protrusions of cytoplasm from one end 
resembling a tennis racket (tadpole cells) can be seen. Beneath the vaginal epithelium, the tumor 
cells are crowded in a cambium layer, in the dermis.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is false regarding precursor squamous epithelial lesions of the cervix?

options.a: LSIL progress directly to invasive carcinoma
options.b: LSILs are 10 times more common than HSILs
options.c: HPV-16 is the most common HPV type in both LSIL and HSIL
options.d: They progress to invasive carcinoma over many years

questions.explanation:
Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL) does not progress directly to invasive 
carcinoma. They initially progress to a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL), then 
invasive carcinoma. The WHO currently recommends a 2-tier system of classification for cervical lesions - low and 
high-grade intraepithelial lesions (LSIL and HSIL). HPV-16 is the most common HPV type 
associated with both LSIL and HSIL LSILs are 10 times more common than HSILs. Most of these lesions regress 
spontaneously. Progression to invasive carcinoma is unpredictable and can take place over years.

questions.question: Question 6: What is the most common type of human papilloma virus causing cervical carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Human papillomavirus (HPV)-16 is the most common type of HPV causing cervical carcinoma. It 
accounts for almost 60% of cervical cancer cases. The ability of HPV to act as a carcinogen depends on the viral proteins E6 and E7. These proteins 
interfere with the activity of tumor-suppressor proteins that regulate cell growth and survival. • E6 - binds with p53 gene and promote its degradation • E7 - binds with RB gene and promotes its degradation

questions.question:
Question 7: A young woman comes to the gynecology OPD for cervical cancer screening. What is the 
staining technique used for this?
questions.explanation:
Cervical cancer screening test, commonly known as Pap smear, is stained using the Papanicolaou 
method. The time for initiating Pap smear screening is 21 years, regardless of the age of first sexual 
intercourse. 865 
Sold by @itachibot The sample is collected using Ayre's spatula and endocervical brush. 2 samples are taken: • 1st slide - prepared from a sample taken from portio vaginalis of the cervix • 2nd slide - prepared from the sample taken from the endocervix (transformation zone) 95% ethanol is used as a fixative. It is a highly specific test. Colposcopic examination and biopsy are recommended in case of 
abnormal Pap smear results.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is incorrect about type I endometrial carcinoma?

options.a: It is associated with obesity and diabetes
options.c: Smoking is a high risk factor
options.d: It is caused by unopposed estrogen stimulation

questions.explanation:
Smoking is strongly associated with mucinous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary, but 
not endometrial carcinoma. Endometrial carcinoma is the most common invasive cancer of the female genital tract. Type 1 
endometrial carcinoma shows endometrioid morphology and is associated with: • Unopposed estrogen exposure (endometrial hyperplasia) • Obesity • Diabetes mellitus • Hypertension PTEN tumor-suppressor gene is mutated in approximately 20% of endometrial hyperplasias. Genomic sequencing of endometrial carcinoma has revealed 4 major molecular subtypes of 
endometrioid and serous carcinomas: • Ultramutated/ POLE tumors - mutations in DNA polymerase  (POLE) • Hypermutated/ MSI (microsatellite instability) tumors - mutations involving mismatch repair 
genes • Copy number low/ MSS (microsatellite stable) tumors - mutations involving the PI3K/AKT 
pathway • Copy number high/ serous-like tumors - TP53 mutations and numerous genomic copy number 
variants

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is not a criterion to distinguish leiomyosarcoma from leiomyoma?
questions.explanation:
The size of the tumor is not a criterion to distinguish between leiomyosarcoma and leiomyoma. The following features are seen in leiomyosarcomas: • Mitotic index - 10 mitoses / 10 hpf • Nuclear atypia - in the presence of nuclear atypia, 5 mitoses / 10 hpf • Tumor cell necrosis - • Characterized by an abrupt transition from viable to non-viable areas 866 
Sold by @itachibot • Within the necrotic zones, atypical cells can be seen

questions.question:
Question 10: Histopathological examination of an ovarian mass sent to the pathology department revealed 
the following. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

options.a: It is more common in women with low parity
options.b: The pathogenesis is related to family history and heritable mutations
options.c: High-grade tumors are associated with TP53 mutations

questions.explanation:
The given image denotes Psammoma bodies which are a histopathological finding seen in ovarian 
papillary serous cystadenoma and cystadenocarcinoma. These tumors are most 
commonly bilateral. The majority of serous tumors of the ovary are benign or borderline. But the serous carcinomas of 
the ovary include the most common malignant tumors of the ovary. Nulliparity, family history, and heritable mutations play a role in the development of these 
tumors. Mutations in the oncogenes KRAS, BRAF, or ERBB2 result in low-grade tumors, and 
mutation in TP53 is associated with high-grade tumors. 867 
Sold by @itachibot There is a higher frequency of carcinoma in women with low parity. Women on oral contraceptive 
pills or those who have undergone tubal ligation are at a lower risk. The marker for ovarian 
tumors is CA-125.

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following is false regarding mucinous tumors of the ovary?

options.c: It occurs principally in middle adult life
options.d: Mutation of the KRAS proto-oncogene is seen

questions.explanation:
The vast majority of mucinous tumors of the ovary are benign or borderline tumors (not 
malignant). It occurs principally in middle adult life and is rare before puberty and after menopause. The 
surface of the ovary is rarely involved, they are rarely bilateral. It is associated with the mutation 
of KRAS proto-oncogene. Grossly it is multiloculated and filled with sticky, gelatinous fluid (rich in glycoproteins).

questions.question:
Question 12: 856 
Sold by @itachibot A 30-year-old woman underwent an evaluation for an abdominal mass. A laparotomy was 
decided upon for the removal of the mass. The gross appearance of the mass is as follows. 
Histopathological examination revealed no malignant change. What is the most likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and image showing unilocular cystic space containing hair and sebaceous 
material are suggestive of mature teratoma. 868 
Sold by @itachibot Dermoid cysts or mature teratomas are benign tumors, usually found in young women during the 
active reproductive years. It is bilateral in 10% to 15% of cases. Microscopically, the cyst wall is composed of tissues from all 3 germ layers. This includes 
stratified squamous epithelium, with underlying sebaceous glands, hair shafts, and other skin 
adnexal structures. Sometimes cartilage, bone, thyroid, and neural tissue can be seen. About 1% of the dermoids undergo malignant transformation, most commonly to squamous cell 
carcinoma. It can also transform into other cancers (e.g., thyroid carcinoma, melanoma). 869 
Sold by @itachibot The component tissue of immature malignant teratomas resembles embryonal and immature fetal 
tissue. It often consists of primitive neuroepithelial cells. The tumor is found chiefly in 
prepubertal adolescents and young women, the mean age being 18 years. Monodermal or specialized teratomas: • Struma ovarii - composed entirely of mature thyroid tissue, which may be functional and cause 
hyperthyroidism. • Ovarian carcinoid - arises from intestinal tissue, may be functional causing carcinoid syndrome 
in the absence of hepatic metastasis

questions.question:
Question 13: A 45-year-old woman presented to the gynecology OPD with a history of abdominal pain and 
distension of abdomen. Ultrasound imaging revealed tumor in the right ovary. Serum level of 
inhibin was raised. The histopathology of the tumor is given below. What is the most likely 
diagnosis? 857 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology showing Call-Exner bodies are suggestive of 
granulosa cell tumor. Call-Exner bodies are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material 
resembling immature follicles. Additionally, small, cuboidal to polygonal cells are seen which may 
grow in anastomosing cords, sheets, or strands. 870 
Sold by @itachibot Granulosa cell tumors are composed of cells that resemble granulosa cells of a developing ovarian 
follicle. It can be of adult and juvenile types. Elevated tissue and serum levels of inhibin, a product 
of granulosa cells, are associated with this tumor. Mutations of the FOXL2 gene are seen in most adult granulosa cell tumors.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 12-year-old girl, who is yet to attain her menarche, presents with an ovarian mass. Her 
serum biomarkers are normal except for elevated AFP. Staging laparotomy was performed 
and the histopathological image is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical features and the histopathological image showing Schiller Duval bodies are 
suggestive of endodermal sinus tumors. It is also known as yolk sac tumor. The Schiller-Duval body is a glomerulus-like structure composed of a central blood vessel 
enveloped by tumor cells within a space that is also lined by tumor cells. 871 
Sold by @itachibot It is the second most common malignant tumor of germ cell origin. It is a unilateral tumor usually 
affecting children or young women.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following are sex cord-stromal tumors?
questions.explanation:
Sex cord-stromal tumors include the following: • Granulosa cell tumor • Sertoli cell tumor • Fibroma Brenner tumor is an epithelial tumor and dysgerminoma is a germ cell tumor. 872 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 16: A 40-year-old woman presented with bilateral adnexal masses. Histopathological 
examination of the resected specimen showed sheets of mucin-producing signet-ring cells. 
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology findings are suggestive of metastatic carcinoma of 
the ovary or Krukenberg tumor. It can arise from primary carcinomas of the stomach (most common), colon, appendix, and breast 
(invasive lobular carcinoma). It is often bilateral and on microscopy shows mucin-laden 
signet-ring cells with eccentric hyperchromatic nuclei. Metastatic tumors of the ovary include: • Tumors of Müllerian origin (most common) - the uterus, fallopian tube, contralateral ovary, or 
pelvic peritoneum • Tumors of extra-Müllerian tumors - breast and gastrointestinal tract carcinomas • Pseudomyxoma peritonei - derived from appendiceal tumors • Krukenberg tumor 873 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 17: A 32-year-old woman was diagnosed with molar pregnancy and underwent suction and 
evacuation. The resected specimen is shown below. Histopathological examination revealed 
thin-walled, cystic structures consisting of hydropic villi with extensive trophoblastic 
proliferation along its entire circumference. Immunohistochemistry was negative for p57. 
Which of the following is false about this condition? 859 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: The genetic material is completely maternally derived
options.b: Embryo dies very early in development and therefore is usually not identified
options.c: It is associated with a 2.5% risk of subsequent choriocarcinoma

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and image showing grapelike vesicles are suggestive of a complete 
mole. It results from the fertilization of an egg that has lost its female chromosomes, and as a 
result, the genetic material is completely paternally derived. The pathogenesis of complete mole is as follows: • Androgenesis (most common) - 46XX karyotype stemming from the duplication of the genetic 
material of 1 sperm • Dispermy - 46XX or 46XY karyotype due to fertilization of an empty egg by 2 sperms Microscopically, thin-walled, cystic, grapelike structures consisting of hydropic villi are seen. 
Trophoblastic proliferation involving the entire circumference of the villi is seen. 874 
Sold by @itachibot The embryo dies very early in development and, therefore, is usually not identified. Patients have 
a 2.5% risk of subsequent choriocarcinoma and a 15% risk of the persistent or invasive mole. The following image shows the pathogenesis of molar pregnancy.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 26-year-old woman with a positive pregnancy test presented with vaginal bleeding in the 
first trimester. On examination, grape-like vesicles were noted in the vagina. A transvaginal 
ultrasound revealed the presence of fetal tissues. A suction evacuation was performed. What 
is the most likely karyotype of the evacuated material?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with grape-like vesicles in the vagina and the presence of fetal tissues 
on transvaginal ultrasound are suggestive of partial mole. The karyotype in a partial mole 
is triploid (e.g., 69XXY) or occasionally tetraploid (92XXXY). It results from the fertilization of an egg with 2 sperms. There is an increased risk of persistent 
molar disease but it is not associated with choriocarcinoma. Given below is an image showing the karyotype of molar pregnancy. 875 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 19: What is the most common site of metastasis in gestational choriocarcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Lungs are the most common site of metastasis in gestational choriocarcinoma. It is followed by the vagina, brain, liver, bone, and kidney in descending order of frequency. Gestational choriocarcinomas are malignant neoplasm of trophoblastic cells derived from a 
previously normal or abnormal pregnancy, such as an extrauterine ectopic pregnancy. The hCG 
levels are elevated to levels above those encountered in hydatidiform moles. It 
shows hematogenous spread. It is rapidly invasive and metastasizes widely. Gestational choriocarcinomas are chemosensitive whereas non-gestational choriocarcinomas are 
chemoresistant.

questions.question: Question 20: The genetic profile of malignant mixed Müllerian tumors resembles that of:
questions.explanation:
Malignant mixed Müllerian tumors (MMMTs) are carcinosarcomas whose genetic profile 
closely resembles endometrial carcinomas. They involve mutations in the same genes - PTEN, TP53, and PIK3CA. The usual genetic 
alterations found in sarcomas are absent in MMMTs. MMMTs are endometrial adenocarcinomas with malignant mesenchymal components. The 
mesenchymal component may resemble uterine mesenchymal elements (stromal sarcoma, 
leiomyosarcoma) or contain heterologous malignant cell types (striated muscle, cartilage, adipose 
tissue, and bone). It occurs in postmenopausal women and presents with bleeding. It is associated with a poor 
outcome.

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following are the components of Meig's syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Meigs' syndrome triad includes the following: • Solid benign ovarian tumor (fibroma) • Right-sided hydrothorax • Ascites - disappears after the removal of the tumor Pseudo-Meigs' syndrome is characterized by the following: • Non-malignant ascites • Pleural effusion • Pelvic tumors - other than solid benign ovarian tumors Note: Ovarian fibroma is also associated with nevoid basal cell carcinoma. This association is 
known as Gorlin syndrome. 876 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 22: A 35-year-old woman was operated for an ovarian mass and the sample was sent for 
histopathological examination. The findings are given below. Which of the following is false 
about the given condition? 861 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: Marked dysplasia and hyperproliferative epidermis are seen
options.d: Virtually never develops into an invasive carcinoma

questions.explanation:
The given histopathological image shows large cells with clear cytoplasm (fried egg appearance), 
tumor cells arranged in sheets, and cords of fibrous stroma infiltrated by lymphocytes. These 
findings are suggestive of dysgerminoma. It is highly responsive to radiotherapy. Dysgerminomas are the ovarian counterparts of testicular seminoma. They may occur in 
childhood, but most commonly occur in the 2-3rd decades. It may occur in patients with gonadal 
dysgenesis, including pseudohermaphroditism. The majority of these tumors are unilateral. They 
express OCT-3, OCT4, and NANOG. All dysgerminomas are malignant, but the degree of histologic atypia is variable. Only about 
one-third of these lesions are aggressive. These neoplasms are responsive to chemoradiation, and 
overall survival exceeds 80%. 877 
Sold by @itachibot 878 
Sold by @itachibot Male Genital Tract
